ost_step.1: Since quadrilateral ABCD is a square, each side length is equal to $\sqrt{16} = 4$ inches. Let x represent the height of triangle e. By similar triangles [image], it follows that $$ {1\over{2}}={4}\cdot{x\over{2}}=2x$$ Solving yields $x=1/2$. Thus, rectangle ABED consists of three separate squares; one measuring ($4-\tfrac{1}{2}=1$inch by $1$inch), another measure $(\tfrac{1}{2})$inch by $(\tfrac{1}{2})$inch, plus yet another identical square whose base extends beyond CD. Each small square measures ($\tfrac{1}{2}$inches$\times$$\tfrac{1}{2}$$~$)inches squared, yielding six times such an object produces $$\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^2 \text{sq.}~\text{ins.}= {\color{red} \frac{1}{4}}\quad\text{sq. ins.}$$ Consequently rectangular EAD contains exactly four half-squares giving $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$.
ost_step.2: If instead you were asked about trapezoid AFDE rather than rectangle ABED, would your calculations change? Of course not! Indeed, although both figures contain precisely the same areas as defined above (and hence necessarily share congruence status accordingly), notice how different regions compose them respectively. Because similarity alone does nto guarantee rigidity, geometry proves most reliable here since shapes may vary despite being composed using equivalent parts. For example imagine folding along line CBD creating right angles within corners BCF & CEF whilst simultaneously cutting away portions labeled DCE." Now suppose said shape was actually rotated - say counterclockwise some degree so F became adjacent O opposite N thereby transforming our original construction into something new entirely perhaps even more intricate just waiting discovery :) . Nonetheless regardless any particular orientation chosen remains valid provided every constituent part maintains proportional relationships relative other elements involved ; thus proving true why terms like 'similar', etc., matter immensely when dealing primarily mathematical concepts relating measurements / ratios amongst respective components without relying solely upon visual intuition itself ! Hope everyone enjoyed reading through those mind bending examples :o)! Good luck exploring further topics around transformations too!!

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Each side length of the square ABCD equals the square root of 16 since it is a square with area 16. Thus each side measures 4 inches long ($\sqrt{16} = 4$). Piece E forms one corner triangle inside quadrilateral ADCB such as three other equal right angled triangles make up the rest of the shape so therefore pieced e was formed using sqrt(3)/2 times half the base , here being b=AD . thus BC=(b)(c)/hence CDE shares height h; hypotenuse DE becomes d when applying pythagorean theorem giving us :d²=bc².so DCE’ s legs measure 4inch x 4inch /2 ;hereforcingtheleg lengthsof DCBE tobe alsoequaltooneanothersquarehalfsizeandgiventhatDCESoformedisthetranslationshelfortheshortenedtriangleformadeusingarightangledtriangeasbasefromwhichwecanobtainheightwhendividingthisareaintoasectionsofequalequalareascaledupsideown.therefore,piecesquaresidesmeasurefourwhilesquarer

Since quadrilateral ABCD is a square, each side length is equal to the square root of the area, so each side length is $\sqrt{16}=4$ inches. Let e represent triangle BCE; since it’s equilateral as well having sides also measuring 4 inches, let d denote the altitude drawn from vertex D intersecting BC extended past C through E. By Pythagorean theorem applied to right triangle DEC, \[d= \sqrt{BC^{2} - EC^{2}} =\sqrt{4^{2}-(\dfrac{1}{2}\times 4)^{2}}=2\sqrt{3}.\] Thus \[\text{Area}_{DEC} =\dfrac{1}{2}(EC)(d)=\dfrac{1}{2}(\dfrac{1}{2}4)(2\sqrt{3})=2\sqrt{3},\]\[\therefore \text{area}_{\text{gray}}{}=3^2-(4+\text{area}_{\text{gray}})={16-16+4\sqrt{3}}=4\sqrt{3}.\]
Therefore [asy], fill((2,0)--(4,2)--(4,0)--

Since quadrilateral ABCD is a square, each side length is equal to the square root of the area, so each side length is $\sqrt{16}=4$ inches. Let e represent triangle BCE; since it’s equilateral as well having sides also measuring 4 inches, let d denote the altitude drawn from vertex D intersecting BC extended past C through E. By Pythagorean theorem applied to right triangle DEC, \[d= \sqrt{BC^{2} - EC^{2}} =\sqrt{4^{2}-(\dfrac{1}{2}\times 4)^{2}}=2\sqrt{3}.\] Thus \[\text{Area}_{DEC} =\dfrac{1}{2}(EC)(d)=\dfrac{1}{2}(\dfrac{1}{2}4)(2\sqrt{3})=2\sqrt{3},\]\[\therefore \text{area}_{\text{gray}}{}=3^2-(4+\text{area}_{\text{gray}})={16-16+4\sqrt{3}}=4\sqrt{3}.\]
Therefore [asy], fill((2,0)--(4,2)--(4,0)--

direct_answer.text: First, since quadrilateral $ABCD$ is a square with an area of 16 square inches, we can determine the length of one side as follows: \[(\text{side})^2=16.\] Taking the square root of both sides yields \[\text{side}=4\text{in}\]. Now considering picture above; Triangle ACB forms half of cube ABCDE so angle CBA equals \(90^\circ\). Also note ADBC makes rectangle ABCD whose diagonals AB and CD bisect angles DAC and BCA respectively forming right angles due to Pythagorean theorem applied twice [\[\left( {BD - DB} \right)^{}^{2}+AD^{}^{2}={DC}^{}^{2},\]whereas also:\[AB\,and DC]\] being equal diagonal line segments thus having same value i\.e., \(\mathrm{AB}\,and\,\cancelto{{DC}}{{DB}}\cdot{\mathrm{CB}}+\cancelto{{BD}}^{{AB}}\,\mathrm{DA}\) applying pythagorian theory again produces following equation;\[{BB}^2+{CC}^2={\mathbf{DC}}^2=(AB)\,and\,({DC})\],thus squ

Since quadrilateral ABCD is a square, each side length is equal to the square root of the area, so each side length is $\sqrt{16}=4$ inches. Let e represent triangle BCE; since it’s equilateral as well having sides also measuring 4 inches, let d denote the altitude drawn from vertex D intersecting BC extended past C through E. By Pythagorean theorem applied to right triangle DEC, \[d= \sqrt{BC^{2} - EC^{2}} =\sqrt{4^{2}-(\dfrac{1}{2}\times 4)^{2}}=2\sqrt{3}.\] Thus \[\text{Area}_{DEC} =\dfrac{1}{2}(EC)(d)=\dfrac{1}{2}(\dfrac{1}{2}4)(2\sqrt{3})=2\sqrt{3},\]\[\therefore \text{area}_{\text{gray}}{}=3^2-(4+\text{area}_{\text{gray}})={16-16+4\sqrt{3}}=4\sqrt{3}.\]
Therefore [asy], fill((2,0)--(4,2)--(4,0)--

ost_step.1: Since quadrilateral ABCD is a square, each side length is equal to $\sqrt{16} = 4$ inches. Let x represent the height of triangle e. By similar triangles [image], it follows that $$ {1\over{2}}={4}\cdot{x\over{2}}=2x$$ Solving yields $x=1/2$. Thus, rectangle ABED consists of three separate squares; one measuring ($4-\tfrac{1}{2}=1$inch by $1$inch), another measure $(\tfrac{1}{2})$inch by $(\tfrac{1}{2})$inch, plus yet another identical square whose base extends beyond CD. Each small square measures ($\tfrac{1}{2}$inches$\times$$\tfrac{1}{2}$$~$)inches squared, yielding six times such an object produces $$\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^2 \text{sq.}~\text{ins.}= {\color{red} \frac{1}{4}}\quad\text{sq. ins.}$$ Consequently rectangular EAD contains exactly four half-squares giving $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$.

Since quadrilateral ABCD is a square, each side length is equal to the square root of the area, so each side length is $\sqrt{16}=4$ inches. Let e represent triangle BCE; since it’s equilateral as well having sides also measuring 4 inches, let d denote the altitude drawn from vertex D intersecting BC extended past C through E. By Pythagorean theorem applied to right triangle DEC, \[d= \sqrt{BC^{2} - EC^{2}} =\sqrt{4^{2}-(\dfrac{1}{2}\times 4)^{2}}=2\sqrt{3}.\] Thus \[\text{Area}_{DEC} =\dfrac{1}{2}(EC)(d)=\dfrac{1}{2}(\dfrac{1}{2}4)(2\sqrt{3})=2\sqrt{3},\]\[\therefore \text{area}_{\text{gray}}{}=3^2-(4+\text{area}_{\text{gray}})={16-16+4\sqrt{3}}=4\sqrt{3}.\]
Therefore [asy], fill((2,0)--(4,2)--(4,0)--
